projectDesc.p: "Memorial on the Bones of the Buddha" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: 臣某言：伏以佛者，夷狄之一法耳。
app.rdg: Your humble servant submits: this practice of bowing to the Buddha is merely a philosophy of the Yi and the Di [i.e., people beyond the civilized realm].

app.lem: 自後漢時流入中國，上古未嘗有也。
app.rdg: Flowing into to China during the Later Han, it had not been present in ancient times.

app.lem: 昔者黃帝在位百年，年百一十歲；少昊在位八十年，年百歲；顓頊在位七十九年，年九十八歲；帝嚳在位七十年，年百五歲；帝堯在位九十八年，年百一十八歲；帝 舜及禹，年皆百歲。
此時天下太平，百姓安樂壽考，然而中國未有佛也。
app.rdg: At that time the world was peaceful and happy, the common people living long and joyful lives, but China did not yet have Buddhism.

app.lem: 其後殷湯亦年百歲，湯孫太戊在位七十五年，武丁在位五十九年，書史不言其年壽所極，推其年數，蓋亦俱不減百歲；
app.rdg:
After this, Tang 湯 of Yin 殷 lived to 100 too, Tang's grandson Tai Wu 太戊 was on the throne for 75 years, Wu Ding 武丁 was on the throne 59 years, and although the books of history do not give his final age, if one had to guess it would most likely not fall short of a century.
Tang 湯, Taiwu 太戊 (or Dawu 大戊) and Wuding 武丁 are all regarded as emperors of the Yin 殷, or Shang 商, dynasty, traditionally dated as 1766 to 1122 BCE.

app.lem: 周文王年九十七歲，武王年九十三歲，穆王在位百年：此時佛法亦未入中國，非因事佛而致然也。
app.rdg:
King Wen of Zhou 周文王 lived to be 97, King Wu 武王 lived to 93, King Mu 穆王 ruled for 100 years:
King Wen 文王 was active under the last years of the Shang, while his son King Wu 武王 established the Zhou周dynasty, ruling during the 11th century BCE, and King Mu 穆王, also of the Zhou 周, ruled during the 10th century BCE.
at this time too Buddhism had not yet arrived in China, and this [longevity] was not a result of serving the Buddha.

app.lem: 漢明帝時始有佛法，明帝在位纔十八年耳。
app.rdg:
Buddhism began to arrive in China at the time of Emperor Ming 明 of the Han, and Mingdi was only on the throne for 18 years.
Emperor Ming 明 of the Eastern Han dynasty (25-220 CE), r. 57-75 CE.

app.lem: 其後亂亡相繼，運祚不長。
app.rdg: Afterwards chaos and the fall [of dynasties] followed in quick succession, and no dynasty was fated to last.

app.lem: 宋、齊、梁、陳、元魏已下，事佛漸謹，年代尤促。
app.rdg:
Under the Song 宋, the Qi 齊, the Liang 梁, the Chen 陳, the Yuan Wei 元魏 and their successors, the Buddha was served ever more sincerely, and the [lifespan of their] dynasties became [ever more] especially brief.
The [Liu] Song 宋 (420-479), the Qi 齊 (479-502), the Liang 梁 (550-557) and the Chen 陳 (557-589) were southern dynasties that arose in the southeast of China. The Yuan Wei 元魏, also known as the Northern Wei 北魏, ruled northern parts of China from 386 to 534 CE.

app.lem: 惟梁武帝在位四十八年，前後三度捨身施佛，宗廟之祭不用牲牢，晝日一食止於菜果，其後竟為侯景所逼，餓死臺城，國亦尋滅。
app.rdg:
Only Emperor Wu of the Liang 梁武帝
Emperor Wu of the Liang 梁武帝, r. 502-549.
retained his throne for 48 years; he tried to offer himself to the Buddha three times in all, and cut down the offerings at the Imperial Ancestral Temple - instead of giving livestock [three times per day] this fell to once per day and even then to mere fruit and vegetables. Eventually he was forced out by rebellion and starved at Taicheng 臺城, and soon the dynasty was destroyed too.
Serving the Buddha to seek happiness thus brings only calamity.

app.lem: 由此觀之，佛不足事，亦可知矣。
app.rdg: From this one sees that Buddha is not worth serving - this can be quite clearly understood.
